prompt.p: A 37-year-old male presents feeling generally unwell with ‘flu-like illness that has persisted for over 6 weeks. He feels tired and has some shortness of breath on exertion. He has been intermittently feverish for the last month and has noticed a 10kg weight loss over the same time period.

On examination:
Patient looks pale with areas of bruising over the skin
Observations: normal

On Full Blood Count:
Hb 8.0 g/dL (normal range for male 13–18g/dL)
WCC 9.0 x 109/L (normal range for WCC: 4.0–11.0 x 10 9 /L)
Platelets 51 x 10 9 /L (normal range 150–400 x 10 9 /L)
Bone Marrow Aspirate: Auer rods in blast cells
A diagnosis of acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is made. Which of the following is a feature of AML?

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: High white cell count of granulocytic lineage in the peripheral blood
Blast cells with Auer rod in bone marrow aspirate
High white cell count with mainly mature lymphocytes with ‘smear’ cells in peripheral blood film
Red granules in blast cells from marrow aspirate using periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain

modalFeedback.p: Option C (Blast cells with Auer rod in bone marrow aspirate) is Correct. This finding indicates acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). The presence of immature white cells; leukaemic blast cells, in the peripheral blood is a feature of acute leukemia. Further investigations will be needed to differentiate between myeloid and lymphoid forms:

ul.li: Bone marrow biopsy will usually show increased cellularity with most cells being abnormal blast cells.

Cytochemical staining (using different stains that detect specific proteins, carbohydrates and lipids characteristic of particular cell lineages) helps to distinguish different forms of leukaemia; AML blast cells with Auer rods, acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) blasts and so on.

modalFeedback.p: Option A (Philadelphia chromosome (Ph)) is Incorrect. The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

Option B (High white cell count of granulocytic lineage in the peripheral blood) is Incorrect. A very high white count up to >100x10 9 /L is characteristic of chronic leukaemia. Mainly granulocytic cells at all stages of development are features of chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML).
Option D (High white cell count with mainly mature lymphocytes with ‘smear’ cells in peripheral blood film) is Incorrect. A very high white count up to >100x10 9 /L is characteristic of chronic leukaemia. A high proportion of mature lymphocytes with ‘smear’ cells produced when the blood film is made indicates chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL).
Option E (Red granules in blast cells from marrow aspirate using periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain) is Incorrect. Acute lymphocytic leukaemic (ALL) blasts contain glycogen, which is stained red by PAS. Normal lymphocytes do not contain glycogen.
